title: How to Fasten Off Crochet & Weave in Ends

steps.title: Crochet the final stitch in your pattern.
steps.content: Crochet the final stitch in your pattern. Make the final stitch in your row, just as you normally would before starting extra chain stitches to turn around and move on to the next. Hold the yarn tight enough to maintain your tension but loose enough so that it can slide through your fingers while you crochet. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the yarn, leaving extra to make a working tail.
steps.content: Cut the yarn, leaving extra to make a working tail. Cut the yarn about 4-6" from where it comes off the piece you are working on. This extra yarn is called the tail. If you plan to use the tail to whip stitch the crochet project to another piece (like when you’re attaching granny squares ), measure the edge you want to sew and multiply it by 3 to get the length of the tail. For example, if the edge of your project is 3”, leave a 9” tail.

steps.title: Yarn over your hook and pull through the loop on your hook.
steps.content: Yarn over your hook and pull through the loop on your hook. There’s only one loop on your hook at this point. Catch the yarn tail on your hook and pull it towards the loop as if you were going to make another chain.

steps.title: Pull the yarn all the way through the loop.
steps.content: Pull the yarn all the way through the loop. Now, instead of creating a loop with the yarn, pull the yarn all the way through until you have made a knot. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tug the tail to secure the knot.
steps.content: Tug the tail to secure the knot. Give the tail a firm pull to tighten the loops behind and around it until it looks like your piece ends in a knot. Finish your piece by weaving in the ends.

steps.title: Thread the tail through a tapestry needle.
steps.content: Thread the tail through a tapestry needle. After you fasten off your crochet project, thread the leftover tail through a tapestry needle by pushing the end of the yarn through the needle’s eye. [3] X Research source No yarn needle? No problem! Use a crochet hook to pull the tail through the stitches.

steps.title: Weave the yarn tail along the length of the row.
steps.content: Weave the yarn tail along the length of the row. Take the needle threaded with your tail and weave it back through the tops of the stitches in the row you just completed. [4] X Research source This will hide the tail and keep it from unraveling the knot you just made. Cut off any excess tail.

steps.title: Make your last stitch in the round.
steps.content: Make your last stitch in the round. Crochet the final stitch as you normally would while working in the round. Stop just short of chaining extra to start a new row.

steps.title: Cut your working yarn to create a tail.
steps.content: Cut your working yarn to create a tail. Cut the yarn about 4-6" from where it comes off the piece you are working on. This extra yarn is the tail you use to fasten off your project.

steps.title: Pull the yarn through the final loop.
steps.content: Pull the yarn through the final loop. Yarn over your hook and pull the tail through the loop until the end comes through and you have a loose tail.

steps.title: Thread a tapestry needle
steps.content: Thread a tapestry needle with the yarn tail. Get a tapestry needle and thread the yarn tail through the eye of the needle. [5] X Research source Leave at least 3” of the yarn tail hanging from the needle so it doesn’t pull out of the eye while you work.

steps.title: Push the needle through the other side of the gap in the row.
steps.content: Push the needle through the other side of the gap in the row. The beginning and end of your final round are separated by a V-shaped gap. With your needle and yarn on one side, put the needle under the first stitch on the other side of the gap, past the beginning chain. Pull the tail under both loops to begin a fake chain stitch.

steps.title: Pull the tail to bring the two sides of the V together and close the gap.
steps.content: Pull the tail to bring the two sides of the V together and close the gap. Gently tug the yarn tail until the two edges of the gap line up perfectly to make a smooth edge along the outside of the piece.

steps.title: Use the needle and yarn to loop back and finish the fake chain.
steps.content: Use the needle and yarn to loop back and finish the fake chain. Go back to the last stitch you made on the first side. Put the thread through the back loop of that first stitch from the facing side, and then pull it through. The joined section will look like a normal chain in the outside row, and be completely invisible.

steps.title: Weave the tail into the middle of 3-4 stitches.
steps.content: Weave the tail into the middle of 3-4 stitches. Use the threaded tapestry needle to weave the tail through the previous round, moving through the middle of 3 to 4 stitches. [6] X Research source Pull the yarn through.

steps.title: Turn the piece and weave back in the opposite direction.
steps.content: Turn the piece and weave back in the opposite direction. After weaving through 3-4 stitches, turn the piece and weave the yarn back through the 3 to 4 stitches to the place where you began. [7] X Research source Weave through a different part of the row than you did when weaving through the first time. This will lock the tail in place to prevent it from unraveling. Cut off the excess tail as close to the piece as possible.

steps.title: Weave the tail around the center of the bottom of the amigarumi.
steps.content: Weave the tail around the center of the bottom of the amigarumi. Amigurumi are small, crocheted stuffed dolls that were originally made in Japan but have become popular in the US and UK. [8] X Research source Because amigurumi are three-dimensional, the method for weaving in the ends after fastening the project off is slightly different after you thread the yarn tail through the tapestry needle. Insert the tapestry needle near the beginning of the yarn tail. Weave the needle in and out of a few stitches. Pull the yarn tight, then repeat, moving around the piece. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Trim off the excess tail, leaving a few inches.
steps.content: Trim off the excess tail, leaving a few inches. Pull the tail out of the tapestry needle when you have woven it in a rough circle around the center of the bottom of the piece. Use scissors or the back of your crochet hook to tuck the end of the tail inside the amigurumi. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Join new yarn to the end of a fastened-off row with a slip stitch.
steps.content: Join new yarn to the end of a fastened-off row with a slip stitch. Use a simple slip stitch if you want to add a row to a piece after you’ve already fastened off the last row. Use this technique when changing colors at the end of a row or beginning a crocheted border . Start by making a slipknot in your new yarn. Then, loop the slipknot over the end of the hook. [11] X Research source Insert the hook into the top of the first stitch in the row to join. Make sure to hold the tail of the slipknot to keep it close to the top of the stitches. Yarn over the hook with the new yarn, and then pull it through the loop on your hook. [12] X Research source Yarn over a second time and pull through the loop on your hook again. Congratulations! Your new yarn is joined to your project. You can continue with the pattern you’re following.
